metadata.title: Alumina catalyst with high density of medium acid sites for N-arylpyrrolidines synthesis

Alumina catalyst with high density of medium acid sites for N-arylpyrrolidines synthesis Yingkang Chen a Hang Zhang a Hongmei Li a Junhua Hu c Yan Long a b ⁎ Min Liu a ⁎⁎ a Hunan Joint International Research Center for Carbon Dioxide Resource Utilization, State Key Laboratory of Powder Metallurgy, School of Physics and Electronics, Central South University, Changsha 410083, PR China Hunan Joint International Research Center for Carbon Dioxide Resource Utilization, State Key Laboratory of Powder Metallurgy, School of Physics and Electronics, Central South University Changsha 410083 PR China School of Physics and Electronics, Central South University, Changsha, 410083, PR China b Guangdong Key Laboratory of Environmental Pollution and Health, School of Environment, Jinan University, Guangzhou 511443, PR China Guangdong Key Laboratory of Environmental Pollution and Health, School of Environment, Jinan University Guangzhou 511443 PR China Guangdong Key Laboratory of Environmental Pollution and Health, School of Environment, Jinan University, Guangzhou 511443, PR China c School of Materials Science and Engineering, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou, PR China School of Materials Science and Engineering, Zhengzhou University Zhengzhou PR China School of Materials Science and Engineering, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou, China ⁎ Corresponding author at: School of Physics and Electronics, Central South University, Changsha 410083, PR China. School of Physics and Electronics, Central South University Changsha 410083 PR China ⁎⁎ Corresponding author. The N-alkylation of amines with tetrahydrofuran (THF) to synthesize pyrrolidine compounds is an economic and environmental benign route. However, current catalytic system often suffered from harsh reaction condition and hazardous reagents. In this work, we developed an alumina nanosheet catalyst with a large amount of medium acid sites for synthesis of N-arylpyrrolidines. Nearly 100% target product yield could be obtained at 190 °C, and this catalyst could be reused at least 5 times without obvious deactivation. NH3-temperature programmed desorption (TPD) and pyridine-infrared (py-IR) revealed that the catalytic performance is positively correlated with the content of medium acid sites. In-situ IR spectrum proved that the reaction follows the carbocation mechanism. This work affords a competitive system for green sustainable chemistry. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords N-arylpyrrolidines Heterogeneous catalyst Alumina Medium acid site Carbocation 1 Introduction Pyrrolidine and its derivatives, as important structural motifs, widely exist in pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, organic materials, and bioactive molecules [1–9]. For example, N-arylpyrrolidines can be used to synthesis antibiotics, diuretics, and other chemicals ( Fig. 1) [10–14]. Many synthetic methods for the formation of N-arylpyrrolidines have been reported, including 1) reductive amination of dicarbonyl compounds [15–17] and 2) reaction of halogenated alkanes or aryl halide with amines [18–26]. However, these synthetic routes not only require toxic raw materials but also possess environment pollution. For example, employing toxic halohydrocarbon as raw material produces large number of inorganic acid by-products, which needs NaOH for neutralization and generates a great deal of waste salts. The N-alkylation of primary arylamines with 1,4-butanediol [27–31] or tetrahydrofuran (THF) [32–41] to N-arylpyrrolidines has attracted wide attention in both industry and academia due to its simple operation process, cheap raw materials and water as the sole by-product. To achieve high selectivity and yield of N-arylpyrrolidines, large number of homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts have been studied. Homogeneous catalysts, such as AlCl3 [32], AlMe3 [38], B(C6F5)3 with TsOH [34], HI [42], POCl3 with DBU [43], and etc., showed excellent catalytic performances, could efficient synthesized N-arylpyrrolidines from primary arylamines and THF at lower temperature. However, the homogeneous catalysts are difficult to reuse, and the toxic or explosive reagents, like AlMe3 or POCl3, etc., are needed for the homogeneous catalytic systems. In contrast, heterogeneous catalysts are advantageous for its easy separation and recycle properties. Unfortunately, even much effort has been made, current heterogeneous catalysts, such as Al2O3 [27,39–41] and TiO2 [37], still suffer from harsh reaction conditions and low target product yield. For example, Minkina et al. [39] reported the synthesis of N-phenylpyrrolidine from aniline and THF over Al2O3 with only 46% yield of target product at extremely high reaction temperature (400 °C). Hargis et al. [37] achieved 93% N-phenylpyrrolidine yield at 300 °C with TiO2 catalyst. Therefore, developing efficient heterogeneous catalyst for synthesis of N-arylpyrrolidines under mild conditions is highly desired. Acidity, as the basic attribute of the catalyst, is one of the main factors affecting the catalytic performance [44–47]. Yong et al. [48] found that the content of medium acid sites of the catalyst can significantly affect the catalytic performance in the N-alkylation reaction. Thus, we predict that the catalytic performance for synthesis of N-arylpyrrolidines might be also correlated with the content of medium acid sites. In order to verify this hypothesis, we selected alumina material with highly adjustable surface acidity for research. According to previous studies, alumina only has Lewis (L) acid site [49], and the strength and content of acid sites are correlated with the main surface-exposed crystal planes [50–53], which can be controlled by different synthetic method [54]. Herein, we synthesized Al2O3 catalysts with different content of medium acid sites, and the Al2O3 nanosheets catalyst with high density medium acid sites exhibits excellent catalytic performance for the synthesis of N-arylpyrrolidines from aniline derivatives and THF. Detailed studies revealed that the medium acid sites are the main active sites, and their contents are positively correlated with the catalytic performance. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation All solvents and chemicals were obtained commercially and used as received. A series of Al2O3 samples were prepared by different chemical synthetic method and denoted as Al2O3-A, Al2O3-B, and Al2O3-C, respectively. Al2O3-A was synthesized by simple precipitation method. Briefly, 3.0 g of Al(NO3)3∙9H2O (Aladdin, 99%) was dissolved in 80 mL of deionized water, and 0.5 M Na2CO3 (Aladdin, 99.8%) solution was slowly added until pH 5.0. The mixture was stirred for 1 h and aged for 5 h. The obtained product was washed with deionized water and ethanol, dried in vacuum at 60 °C for 8 h, and finally calcined in air at 600 °C (5 °C/min) for 4 h. Al2O3-B was prepared by soft template method. Typically, 15.0 g of boehmite (Macklin) and 1.25 g of oleic acid (Aldrich, 90%) were mixed in 100 mL of deionized water at 80 °C. Then, the solution was adjusted to pH 8.5 by the addition of NH3∙H2O (Sinopharm, 25%) under magnetic stirring at 80 °C for 8 h. The mixture was transferred into a 1 L Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and kept at 180 °C for 72 h. After cooling to room temperature, the obtained product was filtrated and washed with ethanol three times, dried at 80 °C for 5 h, and finally calcined in air at 550 °C (2 °C/min) for 8 h. Al2O3-C was synthesized by combining sol-gel method and hydrothermal method. Generally, 10.0 g of aluminium isopropoxide (Aladdin, 98.5%) was dissolved in 100 mL of isopropyl alcohol (Aladdin, 99.5%) and stirred for 8 h. Then, 10 mL of deionized water was added dropwise to the abovementioned solution and stirred for 30 min. The mixture was transferred into a 150 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and kept at 110 °C for 1 h. After cooling to room temperature, the obtained product was dried under 80 °C for 12 h, and calcined in air at 600 °C (5 °C/min) for 4 h. ZrO2 was synthesized by precipitation method. Typically, 8.0 g of ZrOCl2∙8H2O (Aladdin, 99%) was dissolved in 100 mL of methanol (Aladdin, 99.5%), added 10 mL of H2O2 (Sinopharm, 30%). Then, the solution was adjusted to pH 8.0 by the addition of NH3∙H2O under magnetic stirring for 1 h, and then aged for 3 h. The resulting gel mixture was washed with deionized water three times, dried in an oven at 80 °C overnight, and calcined at 650 °C (2 °C/min) in air for 8 h. TiO2 (Aladdin, 99.8%) and SiO2 (Aladdin, 99.9%) were purchased from Aladdin Chemicals and dehydrated at 110 °C for 4 h. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained by using a STADIP automated transmission diffractometer, operated at 36 kV and 20 mA by using CuKa1 radiation. The XRD patterns were scanned in the 2 Theta range of 15–90 °. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained by JEOL 3010 operated at 200 kV. The finely ground sample was dispersed in ethanol and then dropped onto a copper grid for TEM testing. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area and pore size distribution of the catalysts were determined by N2 adsorption-desorption analysis using AUTOSORB IQ. Prior to measurements, the samples were degassed at 300 °C for 6 h, at a rate of 10 °C∙min-1. NH3-temperature programmed desorption (TPD) was performed by using a PCA-1200 on a chemisorption analyzer equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The chemisorption analyzer was PCA-1200 from Beijing Builder electronic technology Co., Ltd. For each experiment, the weighed sample (100 mg) was pretreated at 600 °C (10 °C/min) for 2 h under Ar (30 mL/min) and cooled to room temperature. Then the NH3 gas (30 mL/min) was introduced instead of Ar at this temperature for 1 h to ensure the saturation adsorption of NH3. The sample was then purged with Ar for 1 h (30 mL/min) until the signal returned to the baseline as monitored by a TCD. The desorption curve of NH3 was acquired by heating the sample from room temperature to 800 °C (10 °C/min) under Ar with the flow rate of 30 mL/min. Pyridine-infrared (py-IR) spectra of samples were analyzed by a Thermo IS-50 Fourier Transform infrared (FTIR) spectrometer. The sample was heated at 500 °C for 5 h, and cooled to room temperature. Then, vacuumized to 10–3 Torr, samples were exposed to pyridine vapour (3000 Pa) at 100 °C for 1 h, followed by reevacuation for 1 h, and lower the temperature to take out our samples. After this step, the sample was analyzed by FTIR. In-situ IR spectra of sample was also analyzed by a Thermo IS-50 FTIR spectrometer. Self-supported wafer was prepared from catalyst powder (ca. 10 mg). The wafer was loaded into an in-situ IR thermal catalytic cell with CaF2 windows and pretreated under Ar flow at 300 °C for 2 h. After cooling to room temperature, two channels of Ar gas passed through aniline and THF raw material bottles heated at 60 °C respectively, and then pumped into the in-situ IR cell at the same time. After reaching the equilibrium, recorded the background signal. Subsequently, the temperature was raised to 190 °C, and the spectra were recorded with time. 2.3 Procedure for N-alkylation of aniline and THF A mixture of aniline (40 mmol), THF (48 mmol), catalyst (0.5 g) were placed in a 25 mL autoclave and exchanged with Ar. The reaction was carried out at 190 °C (reaction temperature) for 10 h with a magnetic stirring speed of 500 rpm/min. After the reaction finished, the reaction products were identified and quantified using Shimadzu gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) QP2020 NX using biphenyl as internal standard, and equipped with a 30 m Rtx-5MS fused silica column (i.d. 0.25 mm; 0.25 µm film thickness). The products were isolated by silica column (hexane) separation. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization In order to reveal the structure features of the catalysts, all alumina samples were characterized by XRD, TEM and BET. The XRD spectra present the characteristic peaks of γ-Al2O3 (JCPDS: 10–0425, Fig. 2), indicating that the alumina samples have similar γ-Al2O3 crystal structure. The difference of the peak intensity and width at half height illustrate that the alumina samples have different size. The morphology of alumina samples was characterized by TEM, as shown in Fig. 3. It can be observed that the Al2O3-A, Al2O3-B and Al2O3-C samples consist of nanoparticles with a size of ~2 nm, nanorods with ~90 nm in length and ~4 nm in diameter, and nanosheets with a thickness of ~3 nm, respectively, which accords with the calculation results of XRD signal. According to BET results (Table S1), the surface area of Al2O3-A, Al2O3-B and Al2O3-C are 98.07 m2/g, 142 m2/g and 233.75 m2/g, respectively. Al2O3-C with nanosheet structure has the largest surface area, which means that it may expose more surface active sites. Other metal oxide, as control samples, were also characterized. The corresponding characteristic peaks of ZrO2 (JCPDS: 86–1450), TiO2 (JCPDS: 21–1276) and SiO2 (JCPDS: 29–0085) are detected by XRD (Fig. S1). TEM tests (Fig. S2) show that these metal oxides all have nanosheet morphologies. BET measurements show that ZrO2, TiO2 and SiO2 samples have surface area of 21.52 m2/g, 62.58 m2/g and 198.11 m2/g (Table S2), respectively, which has the similar trend to that of the synthesized Al2O3 samples. 3.2 Acidity of catalysts In order to quantitatively analyze the surface acidity of the catalysts, NH3-TPD was performed ( Fig. 4). It was found that all samples possessed two desorption peaks. The desorption peak before 200 °C can be attributed to weak acid sites, and the desorption peak between 200 °C and 400 °C can be attributed to medium acid sites [55–58]. The quantitative analysis results ( Table 1) show that Al2O3-C has the largest medium acid content of 49.1 μmol/g, which is much higher than that of Al2O3-A with 16.2 μmol/g and Al2O3-B with 29.7 μmol/g, following the trend of surface area changes. In addition, the medium acid content of ZrO2 and TiO2 are 30.3 μmol/g and 30.4 μmol/g, respectively, which are similar to that of Al2O3-B. Notably, SiO2 has no medium acid sites at all. These results demonstrated that the content of medium acid sites is affected by multiple factors such as surface area, morphology and element composition, and it was found to decrease in the order of Al2O3-C > Al2O3-B ≈ ZrO2 ≈ TiO2 > Al2O3-A > SiO2. Next, Py-IR was used to qualitatively analyze the surface acidity ( Fig. 5 and Fig. S3). As shown in Fig. 5, pyridine adsorption bands at 1444, 1570, 1593 and 1610 cm-1 could be detected on the alumina samples, indicating only the L acid exists in the samples [59]. The number of acid sites is related to the Py-IR signal intensity [60]. At the desorption temperature of 100 °C, the signal intensities of Al2O3-A, Al2O3-B and Al2O3-C increase with the surface areas. Their total acid content also follows this order. As the desorption temperature increases to 200 °C, the pyridine is desorbed from the weak acid site, and only the strong acid site exists adsorbed pyridine. Among them, Al2O3-C has the highest adsorption band intensity, which proves that Al2O3-C has the most medium acid sites. These results are consistent with the NH3-TPD results. 3.3 Catalytic tests To verify our prediction, we evaluated the catalytic performance of different samples for the synthesis of N-phenylpyrrolidine from aniline and THF ( Table 2). Obviously, the Al2O3-C shows the best catalytic activity with almost 100% yield of N-phenylpyrrolidine at 190 °C. With medium acid sites decrease, Al2O3-B and Al2O3-A exhibit poor catalytic performances with the target product yield from 58.05% to 4.26%. Similarly, 56.94% and 35.9% yields of N-phenylpyrrolidine were obtained when ZrO2 and TiO2 employed. While, with no medium acid site, no activity could be detected on SiO2. These results indicated the catalytic performances are positively correlated with the content of medium acid sites. To optimize the reaction conditions, the effects of temperature and reaction time were investigated. When the reaction temperature increased from 160 °C to 190 °C, the yield of N-phenylpyrrolidine promoted from 20% to ~100% (entries 3, 7–8, Table 2). On the other hand, when the reaction time was extended from 8 h to 10 h, the target product yield was rose from 77.5% to ~100% (entries 3, 10, Table 2). Further increasing temperature to 200 °C or extending time to 12 h, the N-phenylpyrrolidine yield was unchanged (entry 9, 11, Table 2), indicating that 10 h reaction at 190 °C is the optimal reaction condition. The stability of the catalyst was also evaluated ( Fig. 6). After each test, the collected catalyst was dried at 60 °C for 8 h, and then calcined for 3 h at 500 °C under an ambient atmosphere to remove the adsorbed N-phenylpyrrolidine on the catalyst. To our delight, the catalyst can maintain the high catalytic performance after several times recycling. A remarkable 93.9% yield of N-phenylpyrrolidine can still be obtained after 5 runs (entry 12, Table 2). The catalyst after 5 times recycling was characterized by BET, NH3-TPD and py-IR (Table S3 and Figs. S4 and S5). It was found that the surface area and the content of medium acid sites slightly decreased after reaction, which was the reason for slight deactivation of the catalyst. This recycling experiment proves good stability of the catalyst. 3.4 Substrate expand The substrate range of Al2O3-C catalyst was further studied, as shown in Table 3. A series of arylamines for synthesis corresponding N-arylpyrrolidines were tested. And the arylamines bearing electron-donating or electron-withdrawing groups are all suitable for this reaction, with the target N-arylpyrrolidines yield from 61% to ~100% (entries 2–17, Table 3). According to the results in Table 3, the nature of the substituent groups has little effect on the product yield (entries 2–4, 14–17, Table 3). The main factor affecting the product yield is steric hindrance due to the introduction of substituent group. The size of steric hindrance is affected by both the size and position of the substituent group. Therefore, for the same group, the product yield of ortho- group substitution is always less than that of meta- and para- groups (entries 2–4, 14, 15, Table 3). Likewise, at the same position, larger group will have smaller product yield (entries 3, 4, 10–13, Table 3). These results demonstrated Al2O3-C has good substrate tolerance. 3.5 Catalytic mechanism In order to clarify the reaction mechanism, we used in-situ IR spectroscopy to test the changes of reactants at 190 °C ( Fig. 7). The initial state showed aniline bands at 3367 and 3440 cm-1 [61], and THF bands at 960 and 1080 cm-1 before heating. After the temperature increased, new signal bands, such as C-O band in saturated aliphatic ether at 1125 cm-1 [62] and carbocation bands at 1507 and 1543 cm-1 [63,64], were detected. With the reaction proceeds, the signal intensity of the aniline bands decreased rapidly and disappeared completely after 4 min’ reaction, indicated that the alumina catalyst does not interact with aniline. The THF band shifted from 1080 cm-1 to 1125 cm-1, which is the feature of the THF ring-opening step [62], proved that the main reactant on Al2O3 is THF. Combined with the detected carbocation bands, this reaction follows the carbocation mechanism. Based on the carbocation mechanism and medium acid sites as the main active center, we proposed a possible catalytic reaction mechanism ( Fig. 8). According to Pejov and Kassab’s studies, the acid strength is related to the coordination number of the aluminum atom, lower coordination numbers higher acid strength [65,66]. Therefore, high acid sites with low-coordination Al shows strong electron-withdrawing properties to adsorb oxygen atoms from THF, weakening the C-O bond until the THF ring-opening to form the carbocation intermediates A. Then, the lone pair electron on the aniline nitrogen atom carries out a nucleophilic attack on the carbocation to form intermediates B. At last, dehydration and ring closure generate N-phenylpyrrolidine and water as by-product. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, we have developed Al2O3 catalyst for heterogeneous catalytic N-alkylation of aniline derivatives and THF under mild conditions. As demonstrated from catalysis test results, NH3-TPD, py-IR spectra and in situ-IR spectra, the reaction followed the carbocation mechanism and the medium acid site was the main active site. It could be found that increased the content of medium acid sites of the catalyst could effectively reduce the reaction temperature and improve the catalytic performance. Al2O3-C catalyst with the largest content of medium acid sites showed the best catalytic performance, which could synthesize a series of N-arylpyrrolidines in high yield (63.7–100%) at 190 °C. Meanwhile, the catalyst could be reused at least 5 times without apparent deactivation. This work may provide an important insight in development of heterogeneous catalyst for the synthesis of N-arylpyrrolidines at low temperature. coredata.dc:description: The N-alkylation of amines with tetrahydrofuran (THF) to synthesize pyrrolidine compounds is an economic and environmental benign route. However, current catalytic system often suffered from harsh reaction condition and hazardous reagents. In this work, we developed an alumina nanosheet catalyst with a large amount of medium acid sites for synthesis of N-arylpyrrolidines. Nearly 100% target product yield could be obtained at 190 °C, and this catalyst could be reused at least 5 times without obvious deactivation. NH3-temperature programmed desorption (TPD) and pyridine-infrared (py-IR) revealed that the catalytic performance is positively correlated with the content of medium acid sites. In-situ IR spectrum proved that the reaction follows the carbocation mechanism. This work affords a competitive system for green sustainable chemistry.
coredata.dc:title: Alumina catalyst with high density of medium acid sites for N-arylpyrrolidines synthesis
